node.text: Twenty million people are under heat alerts in the Western United States. As scorching temperatures bring drought, water restrictions and wildfires, these residents say they've had enough.

node.title: These Americans are fleeing the West because of extreme heat

node.text: One Maine-based startup, Running Tide Technologies, is experimenting with farming kelp, a type of seaweed, in an effort to pull carbon from the air and store it deep beneath the ocean floor, potentially giving the world another nature-based tool to curb climate change.

node.title: This startup wants to pull carbon from the air using kelp

node.text: Russia's Lake Baikal is the oldest and deepest lake in the world, holding about 20% of the world's fresh water and currently facing increasing environmental threats from climate change and mass tourism. As Russia continues to encourage visitors to the lake, even in the midst of the pandemic, some locals question whether the pristine environment is being sacrificed in favor of revenue. CNN's @fpleitgencnn reports from a town in Russia, where some say their home simply can't take on any more people.

node.title: 'This is certainly one of those an environmental ticking time bomb'

node.text: In the north woods of Minnesota, around the frozen Mississippi River, a small-but-growing group of protesters is out to stop a replacement oil pipeline called Line 3. Tribal activists, environmentalists and local residents have build temporary protest camps along the construction route.

node.title: The next Keystone XL fight is here in Minnesota

node.text: San Francisco-based startup, Compology, is using cameras and artificial intelligence to monitor what’s thrown into dumpsters and trash containers at businesses such as McDonald’s restaurants and Nordstrom department stores.

node.text: Global honey bee populations are in decline, putting the world's food supply under pressure. Texas beekeeper Erika Thompson is on a mission to save them, and the videos of her rescue missions have TikTok users buzzing.

node.text: Dams that beavers build can reduce flooding and drought, increase biodiversity, and lower pollution. They were hunted to extinction across Europe for their pelts -- but now they're being reintroduced into the wild in England, and their impact is remarkable

node.text: Methane, or natural gas, is 80 times more potent than carbon dioxide. @billweircnn goes to Texas, where methane is so plentiful and cheap, it escaped largely unseen and unmeasured until recently.

node.title: An invisible gas is pitting Texas against the Biden administration

node.text: With President Biden expected to sign several climate-focused executive actions Wednesday, CNN's Bill Weir looks at the state of the climate crisis using an infrared camera to show methane, a gas 80 times more potent than carbon dioxide, polluting clear blue sky over Texas.

node.title: How President Biden plans to target the climate crisis

node.text: Gillette, Wyoming, is the energy capital of the United States. After the election, resident Steve Gray left CNN a voicemail saying he feared Gillette will become a ghost town under President Joe Biden. CNN contributor John Sutter travels to Gillette to meet Steve and asks: In the fight against the climate crisis, what do we owe the workers who have helped power America for decades?

node.title: This town powered America. Now what?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on August 14, 2021. May be an image of standing, fire, outdoors and text that says 'Climate Wildland firefighters could get $20,000 raise from infrastructure bill ww'.

node.text:
Federal wildland firefighters, who make as little as $13.45 an hour, could get a long-awaited pay raise if the bipartisan infrastructure package making its way through Congress eventually gets to President Joe Biden's desk. The $1 trillion bill, which passed the Senate on Tuesday, would provide $600 million to increase the base salaries for firefighters within the Interior Department and Agriculture Department by up to $20,000 or 50% a year, whichever is less. It would also convert at least 1,000 seasonal firefighters to permanent positions. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
⁠
(📸: Ringo Chiu/AFP/Getty Images)⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on August 12, 2021. May be a meme of body of water and text that says 'Climate Italy may have just registered Europe's hottest day on record'.

node.text:
Authorities in Italy say the island of Sicily may have set an all-time heat record for Europe, hitting a temperature of 48.8 degrees Celsius (119.8 degrees Fahrenheit). A persistent heat wave around the Mediterranean in Europe and North Africa has contributed to some of the worst fires seen there in years. An authoritative report by the UN's International Panel on Climate Change published Monday said that 38 weather conditions that promote wildfires have become more probable in southern Europe over the last century. Globally, the heat waves and droughts worsening fires have increased too. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Giovanni Isolino/AFP/Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on August 11, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing, fire and outdoors.

node.text:
Greece is facing a "natural disaster of unprecedented proportions," as 586 wildfires burn in "all corners" of the country, according to Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis. Southern Europe, where droughts are becoming more frequent and severe, is feeling the impacts of the climate crisis, according to environmental experts.

(📸: Konstantinos Tsakalidis/Bloomberg/Getty Images, Thodoris Nikolaou/AP, Angelos Tzortzinis/AFP/Getty Images, Nicolas Economou/Reuters, Giannis Spyrounis/AP, Angelos Tzortzinis /AFP/Getty Images and Giannis Spyrounis/ilialive.gr/AP)

node.text:
Teenage climate activist Greta Thunberg is the cover star of Vogue Scandinavia's first issue. In an accompanying profile, Thunberg spotlighted the role of fast fashion — the mass production of inexpensive, on-trend clothing that maintains low pricing through labor exploitation and poor quality — in the worsening climate crisis. "If you are buying fast fashion then you are contributing to that industry and encouraging them to expand and encouraging them to continue their harmful process," she told the magazine. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
⁠
(📸: Alexandrov Klum/Vogue Scandinavia)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on August 09, 2021. May be an image of fire and text that says 'Climate The human-caused climate crisis is 'unequivocal,' major UN report says'.

node.text:
A state-of-the-science report from the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change says the world has rapidly warmed 1.1 degrees Celsius higher than pre-industrial levels, and is now careening toward 1.5 degrees — a critical threshold that world leaders agreed warming should remain below to avoid worsening impacts. Only by making deep cuts to greenhouse gas emissions, while also removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, can we halt the precipitous trend. "Bottom line is that we have zero years left to avoid dangerous climate change, because it's here," Michael E. Mann, a lead author of the IPCC's 2001 report, told CNN. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: ANGELOS TZORTZINIS/AFP via Getty Images)⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on August 07, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Climate Number of people exposed to floods is 10 times higher than previous estimates, study finds'.

node.text:
Amid a deadly summer of flooding in different parts of the world, scientists have found the number of people at risk of extreme flooding has grown significantly in the past two decades. In Germany, severe flooding claimed the lives of at least 173 people. In Nigeria, Lagos Island experienced one of its worst floods in recent years, submerging cars and houses. And, earlier this week, officials announced that the death toll from China's July floods had climbed to 302 -- more than triple the previous estimate. Climate change is making extreme flooding worse, and a study published Wednesday in the journal Nature concluded the population exposed to those floods since 2000 is 10 times higher than previous estimates, as more people migrate into flood-prone areas. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: FeatureChina/AP)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on August 05, 2021. May be an image of car, outdoors and text that says 'Climate Biden announces new target that 50% of vehicles sold in US by 2030 are electric DRIVE t SUNSHINE Jeep'.

node.text:
President Biden unveiled another component of his administration's plan to fight the climate crisis on Thursday, announcing a new target that half of vehicles sold in the country by 2030 will be battery electric, fuel-cell electric or plug-in hybrid. Biden said the future of America's car manufacturing "is electric and there's no turning back."⁠
⁠
(📸: Stellantis)

node.text: The Dixie Fire wiped out much of the Greenville community in Northern California when it swept through at alarming speed on Wednesday. “Within two hours, our town was gone,” Greenville resident Teresa Clark told KXTV. “We were sitting outside town about a mile away, and you could hear propane tanks just exploding.” The climate crisis is making more destructive wildfires increasingly common. The Dixie Fire is one of 12 large active fires in California that have seared more than 475,000 acres so far, according to the National Interagency Fire Center.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on August 04, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Climate Heatwave scorches southern Europe as summer of extreme weather rages on Pta'.

node.text:
Extreme heat and wildfires continued to plague parts of southern Europe on Wednesday, a day after the top temperature in Greece reached 117 degrees Fahrenheit — just shy of the highest ever recorded in Europe. Greece is facing one of its worst heatwaves in decades and the country remains on high alert as it continues to battle blazes across the country. Heat warnings were also issued for Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Italy, Romania, Serbia and Turkey. Deadly wildfires have swept across parts of Turkey in recent days and forced the evacuation of tourist resorts. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Yasin Akgul/AFP/Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on August 02, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Climate Battling floods and rising seas, Africa's most populous city soon be unlivable, experts warn may'.

node.text:
Residents of Nigeria are used to the yearly floods that engulf Lagos, a low-lying city on Nigeria's Atlantic coast, during the months of March to November. In mid-July, however, the major business district of Lagos Island experienced one of its worst floods in recent years. Home to more than 24 million people, Africa's most populous city may become uninhabitable by the end of this century as sea levels rise due to climate change, scientific projections suggest. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Adekunle Ajayi/Nurphoto/Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 30, 2021. May be an image of mountain and text that says 'Climate Climate On Tuesday, enough Greenland ice melted to cover Florida in 2 inches of water'.

node.text:
Greenland is experiencing its most significant melting event of the year as temperatures in the Arctic surge. Greenland lost more than 8.5 billion tons of surface mass on Tuesday, and 18.4 billion tons since Sunday, according to the Denmark Meteorological Institute. That would be enough to cover the entire state of Florida in two inches of water. While this week's total ice loss is not as extreme as a similar event in 2019 — a record melt year — the area of the ice sheet that's melting is larger. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Delphotos/Alamy)⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Climate "That fear I felt last year is even worse this year. You walk around with this vague sense of terror.' Eric Beck, a 65-year-old who left Los Angeles for Portland to avoid the city's frequent heatwaves'.

node.text: In ways big and small, the effects of climate change are upending lives across the US. Many residents of the West who spoke with CNN say that they are frightened by the inescapable heat, the explosive wildfires and the unrelenting drought. Last month, an unrelenting heatwave sent temperatures in Portland, Oregon, spiking as high as 116 degrees Fahrenheit. A heat event of this magnitude in the Northwest would have been "virtually impossible" without the huge amounts of heat-trapping gases humans have pumped into the atmosphere, scientists say. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.
